patterns.title: Risk Vs Reward
patterns.front: A mechanic in which players decide whether a potential reward is worth the potential risk or loss.

first_game.title: Rogue
first_game.note: Permadeath and loot tables create constant value tradeoffs.

notables.title: Dark Souls
notables.note: Souls as currency: push deeper or bank safely at a bonfire.

notables.title: FTL
notables.note: Risky events vs. resource scarcity in every jump.

notables.title: Spelunky
notables.note: High-value items guarded by lethal layouts and ghost timer.

patterns.title: Glass Cannon
patterns.front: A high-damage build that trades durability for destructive power. Great for players who want big highs and don’t mind living dangerously.

first_game.title: Final Fantasy
first_game.note: Early mages can delete enemies but collapse if anything looks at them funny.

patterns.title: Safe Zone
patterns.front: A peaceful pocket where tension drops and the player can breathe. Safe Zones reset the emotional pace and make danger feel sharper when it returns.

first_game.title: The Legend of Zelda
first_game.note: Old man caves offered brief safety from monsters and let players mentally reset.

patterns.title: Combo Chain
patterns.front: A sequence of actions that link together into a single escalating payoff. Missing a step breaks the chain and resets the reward.

first_game.title: Street Fighter II
first_game.note: Early combo discovery turned precise input strings into explosive payoff moments.

patterns.title: Fog of War
patterns.front: Parts of the world or information are hidden until the player scouts or reveals them, turning knowledge itself into a resource.

first_game.title: Warcraft: Orcs & Humans
first_game.note: Shrouded maps made scouting and map awareness as important as building armies.

patterns.title: One Button
patterns.front: All core actions are mapped to a single input, forcing depth to come from timing, context, or level design instead of complex controls.

first_game.title: Flappy Bird
first_game.note: A single tap drives the entire game loop, with difficulty coming purely from timing and level layout.

patterns.title: Press and Hold
patterns.front: Holding an input charges or alters an action, trading time and vulnerability for a stronger or different effect.

first_game.title: Mega Man 4
first_game.note: Charging the Mega Buster rewards patience with a powerful shot but leaves the player briefly committed.

patterns.title: Telegraphing
patterns.front: Foes and hazards broadcast their upcoming actions through clear cues, letting players anticipate danger and feel responsible for success or failure.

first_game.title: Punch-Out!!
first_game.note: Boxers signal attacks with distinct animations, making reading tells the core of the gameplay.

patterns.title: Resource-Limited Movement
patterns.front: Every step spends a limited resource like breath, stamina, or fuel. Movement itself becomes a budget you have to manage under pressure.

first_game.title: Rogue
first_game.note: Every step consumes a turn, and hunger depletes over turns.

patterns.title: Environmental Timing Puzzle
patterns.front: The world itself runs on rhythms and cycles—bridges, hazards, and exits move or toggle in time, forcing the player to sync their actions with the environment.

first_game.title: Pitfall!
first_game.note: Wait for vine → grab with perfect timing → leap over crocodiles → move before next log rolls in.

patterns.title: Indirect Control
patterns.front: Instead of steering actors directly, the player changes the world, rules, or timing and lets the system respond. You influence behavior without giving explicit orders.

first_game.title: Lemmings
first_game.note: Players alter the environment and roles instead of steering each lemming by hand.

patterns.title: Spatial Hazard
patterns.front: Specific tiles or regions of the map are dangerous by their very nature—water, pits, spikes, or patrol routes that punish careless positioning.

first_game.title: Adventure
first_game.note: The map includes static threats like pits, labyrinth walls, dragons patrolling certain rooms, and one-hit-kill obstacles you must navigate around.

patterns.title: Soft Reset Loop
patterns.front: Failure sends the player back to the start of a short loop instead of erasing long-term progress, encouraging experimentation instead of punishment.

first_game.title: Donkey Kong
first_game.note: When Mario dies, the game instantly resets the current stage without pushing the player back to the beginning of the entire game.

patterns.title: Short-Stage Loop
patterns.front: Levels are brief, focused challenges that can be retried quickly. The game’s pacing comes from many small loops instead of a few big ones.

first_game.title: Pac-Man
first_game.note: After clearing a board, Pac-Man instantly transitions to the next short loop — same core rules, slightly higher difficulty.

patterns.title: Gradual Rule Introduction
patterns.front: New rules and mechanics appear one at a time, layered on top of what the player already understands, so complexity ramps up without overwhelming them.

first_game.title: Super Mario Bros.
first_game.note: World 1-1 -- The level literally teaches a player how to play without a single on-screen instruction

patterns.title: Minimalist Feedback
patterns.front: The game uses simple, clean cues instead of flashy effects—just enough sound, motion, or color to communicate state without visual noise.

first_game.title: Pong
first_game.note: The sound of the ball bouncing is the only signal you need to understand the state of play. No text, no UI clutter, no animation flair.
